intro: Haplopappus bellidioides, commonly known as the desert flax, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of North America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its leaves are narrow and linear, and it produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in the spring. Haplopappus bellidioides is often found in disturbed areas and is considered a pioneer species in ecological succession.
